title: Cannot update with AppLocker

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Issue Type: Bug Hi, VSCode cannot be updated from menu _Help -> Install update_ with enabled Applocker. The reason is unsigned TMP file "%OSDRIVE%\USERS\%username%\APPDATA\LOCAL\TEMP\IS-BOHH9.TMP\CODESETUP-STABLE-5F24C93878BD4BC645A4A17C620E2487B11005F9.TMP (or similar) was prevented from running." You have to use update service (as google chrome) or evaluate permission before starting update. Because not every one is working with administrator rights. title: editor.insertSnippet() messes with indenting of the SnippetString
language aware auto indent
body:
Issue Type: Bug There are couple of examples, one in PHP, another one in JS: ``` // PHP code: DB::table('my_table') ->select([ 'my_field' ]) ->where('type', 'plain') ->get();***cursor is here*** ``` ``` // JS code: $('.my-button') .on('click', () => alert('Clicked');***cursor is here*** ``` In both cases, pressing Enter would make new line indented just like the previous one (col 8). However, it should indent to be matching the line where the "flow-style" construction started (col 4). VS Code version: Code 1.29.0 (5f24c93878bd4bc645a4a17c620e2487b11005f9, 2018-11-12T07:39:38.932Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.2.0

They keep moving around so I paused it to inspect the page

title: Feature Request Add favorites
body: Can you add in the Welcome page, a list of favorite projects that the user will set? For example i am working on 3 projects but the recent projects is not helping. I would want to have a panel that i can set my favorites and with a click to open the folder.

title: Provide workspace Uri when a terminal has been created
body:
Right now when a terminal is created the `onDidOpenTerminal` event fires providing the ref to the `terminal` created.

This information is crucial for the Python Extension when activating the Python Environment in the terminal.

Note: Each workspace folder can have different python environments, hence the workspace folder Uri is necessary when identifying the python environment that needs to be activated.

**Suggestion**: Add `workspaceUr` or `cwd` to the `Terminal` object.

title: Ability to apply a final sort to QuickPick results
body: I'd like to be able to pin certain items to the top of a QuickPick list, but the QuickPick's fuzzy matching functionality doesn't allow any custom sorting. Providing some kind of hook to apply a final sort would solve this. This hook would receive the fuzzy-matched order and could return a new array for the final order.

title: Add action to move caret by word
body: Would it be possible to add a keybinding option to move caret by word? i.e. Take the existing `editor.action.moveCarret` bindings and expand them to move by word like the `cursorWord` actions? It would be nice to be able to move selections left/right along a line more than one character at a time.

title: Center layout autoresize with integrated terminal

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
In #53989 there was implemented nice behaviour for center layout! Thanks! *But* a split mode isn't the only way when you reduce width of the editor area.
So I think (and I know it on my own though) it will be useful to add similar behaviour when integrated terminal is toggled and it's vertical.
1. Single editor mode. Center layout enabled
2. Toggle vertical integrated terminal
3. Center layout disabled.
And vice versa...

In addition: it seems reasonable to add it also to switching terminal from horizontal to vertical...

title: Issue reporter: Detect language and suggest automatic translation
body: The issue reporter could use Bing Translator (or similar) to detect the entered language and suggest a translation if it is not in English.

title: Recommended XML extension in VS Code
body: Currently, VS Code recommends to install https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=DotJoshJohnson.xml, when an XML document is opened or when you search for XML, in the extensions view: [`redhat.vscode-xml`](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=redhat.vscode-xml) actually has a [**much** larger feature set](https://github.com/redhat-developer/vscode-xml/blob/master/README.md#features) and is actively maintained. I wonder which criteria determine how an extension should be the recommended one for a given language. Is it based on max number of installations alone? I remember how, for Java, the recommendation was sort of hard-coded to promote Microsoft's Java Extension pack. cc @auchenberg, @egamma, @aeschli, @akaroml, @gorkem, @NikolasKomonen

title: Open new file from command line with included text
body: It doesn't look like there's a way to open vscode from the command line and create a file *with some initial text*. Opening and creating a new file is straightforward: `code Foo.txt`, but I want to be able to give Foo.txt some initial text content. e.g. `code Foo.txt -t <Insert some text into Foo.txt>`

title: emmet.includeLanguages for one to many mapping

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
How can I enable several languages for a given file extension please?

For example

```json
"emmet.includeLanguages": {
        "tt": ["html", "css", "javascript"],
    }
```

Except this doesn't work. I tried with multiple references to the key 

```json
"emmet.includeLanguages": {
        "tt": "html",
        "tt": "css",
        "tt": "javascript",
    }
```

and also with an embedded object

```json
"emmet.includeLanguages": {
        "tt": {
        "html":"html",
        "css": "css",
        "javascript": "javascript",
    }
```

no joy :-(


-------------------------------------------------
```json
"emmet.includeLanguages": {
        "erb": "html"
    }
```

_Originally posted by @abnersajr in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9500#issuecomment-339634819_

title: Preserve Current Selection when using snippet with TM_SELECTED_TEXT variable
body:
Currently snippets with prefixes set become rather useless when they contain the selected text variable.

I have a snippet like this:
```
  "lint_checking": {
    "prefix": "lin",
    "body": [
      "//lint_checking ${1:RULE_ID} off",
      "$TM_SELECTED_TEXT",
      "//lint_checking ${1:RULE_ID} on"
    ],
    "description": "lint pragmas"
  }
```
What I want is being able to select text, start typing lin (which will of course remove the selection) and then IntelliSense will recommend lin as a completion. When I press enter I want the selection to reappear, surrounded by my snippet.

This behavior is actually standard in other editors and I was kind of surprised to find no useful way to use snippets with a completion prefix when the selction variable is being used.

If this is unwanted by some users this should be made configurable as an option, but as a hardware developer I find myself in the situation quite often where this would be useful, as such 'surrounding pragmas' are pretty common.

Another variant would be to make snippets able to be promoted to commands for the Ctrl+Shift+P command palette, so we don't have to go into the insert snippet sub palette. I do not want to assign dedicated Key Bindings, as it just becomes to much. The prefix 'is the keybinding'.

title: Feature request: Control Custom views

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I have two requests for custom views : 
1. I would be great if custom views can be expandable conditionally. For example, being able to expand a certain view only after an event occurs. 
2. also , a control mechanisim to define view area usage would be beneficial. We want some views take up less space than others.

title: unify scrollbar onclick behavior with (most) native apps and change Minimap on click behavior
body:
Expected behavior:
On Windows/most Linux DEs, when you click on the scrollbar:
- If you click on the current section, you can drag it to scroll up/down
- **If you click outside the current section, it scrolls up/down(towards clicked point) _by one page_** (If you hold your mouse, it will scroll in that direction continously)

VSCode scrollbar behavior:
- If you click on the current section, you can drag it to scroll up/down
- **If you click outside the current section, it navigates to that position directly.**

VSCode Minimap behavior
- If you click on the current section, you can drag it to scroll up/down
- **If you click outside the current section, it navigates to the mid point of current position and clicked position directly.**


personally, I want VSCode scrollbar acts like a native apps so that it scrolls by one page, and I want the minimap acts like what scrollbar acts rightnow - navigate to clicked position directly. Of course we can just add configs for such behavior so users can choose what they want.

title: Debian repository Packages / Packages.gz / Packages.bz2 contain extra whitespace
body:
The Debian repository Packages{,.gz,.bz2} seem to have an extra line of whitespace that causes parsing issues with python-debian.

This only occurs for 12 of the entries, the other 453 are fine.

To see the 12 with an extra line with whitespace only in the stanza, run:

```
# curl -s http://packages.microsoft.com/repos/vscode/dists/stable/main/binary-amd64/Packages | grep -n -H "^ $"
(standard input):3485:
(standard input):3780:
(standard input):3802:
(standard input):3824:
(standard input):3846:
(standard input):3868:
(standard input):3890:
(standard input):3912:
(standard input):3934:
(standard input):3956:
(standard input):3978:
(standard input):4000:
```

Would it be possible to remove these lines from the Packages files?

title: VS Code should be able to handle file:// URIs

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Version: 1.28.2
Commit: 7f3ce96ff4729c91352ae6def877e59c561f4850
Date: 2018-10-17T00:20:56.183Z
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome: 61.0.3163.100
Node.js: 8.9.3
V8: 6.1.534.41
Architecture: x64
- OS Version: Debian buster/sid

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Ctrl-Click an HTML `file://` URL in `gnome-terminal` like `file:///home/per/git/myproject/build/reports/spotbugs/main.html`
2. A new VSCode window opens, but with an empy `Untitled-1` file instead of the file I tried opening.

No error is shown in the developer console (I verified).

This _seems_ like #25987 have come back, in one form or the other.

For reference, here is the `code.desktop` file:

```ini
$ cat /usr/share/applications/code.desktop
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Visual Studio Code
Comment=Code Editing. Redefined.
GenericName=Text Editor
Exec=/usr/share/code/code --unity-launch %F
Icon=code
Type=Application
StartupNotify=true
StartupWMClass=Code
Categories=Utility;TextEditor;Development;IDE;
MimeType=text/plain;inode/directory;
Actions=new-empty-window;
Keywords=vscode;

X-Desktop-File-Install-Version=0.23

[Desktop Action new-empty-window]
Name=New Empty Window
Exec=/usr/share/code/code --new-window %F
Icon=code
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

Can't really try. :cry:

title: Git: Provide task progress

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
**Request**
It could be a nice feature to show the git progress details in the GIT output console or since Visual Studio even though is 'Code' has the characteristic to being 'Visual', polish the user interface with some indicator. 
In the following images there are some suggestions:
![progress 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8238828/48170162-9c7bee80-e2f6-11e8-830f-7c440c1ef7b2.png)
![progress2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8238828/48170168-a30a6600-e2f6-11e8-807c-817580ac5e84.png)

**Use case**
It happen sometime that users have in their own repository some huge files or maybe the connection slow down during the 'git push', users don't have any idea what is happening or what is the current operation state (it could take even plenty of minutes).
In the example I'have done, this is what is showed actually in VS Code:
![nothappen](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8238828/48170294-2b890680-e2f7-11e8-9737-4397bc03bb06.png)
And this is what it can be read from the git executable output:
![expected](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8238828/48170317-4c515c00-e2f7-11e8-9903-c5816dcc2084.png)

**Advantages**
Users that have this kind of experience can think that the git integration (that is already amazing in VS Code) is not working very good because the operations appears 'blocked'. So they give up and jump on the CLI for the daily usage of git. With some nice improvements like I showed they wouldn't do it.

**Technical inspection**
I inspected the main source code file about the default GIT extension:
[https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/git/src/git.ts](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/git/src/git.ts)
A nice implementation could be extract more information on the 'git commands output' parsing, ex. Operation 'N' of 'M' and 'Percentage', expose it and use on higher layer of Visual Studio Code.

Waiting for a your feedback.

Thank you.

title: Inconsistent TSX indent cursor after end tag
body: - VSCode Version: 1.29.0-insider - OS Version: macOS 10.13.4 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Write two or more nested elements in TSX 2. Make sure language mode is on "Typescript React" 3. Create a blank line after the inner end tag 4. Place cursor at very start of that blank line 5. Hit the tab keyboard key **Observed Behavior:** **Expected Behavior:** Only seems to happen in some spots in the tree. Comparison of behavior in three different locations tested first in TSX, then in an HTML file. HTML mode indents correctly in all three cases. TSX doesn't work in third case: ![kapture 2018-11-07 at 18 28 51](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1341104/48168404-12fbfa80-e2bd-11e8-80da-ce910c411b8d.gif)

title: Add a command to put OS / VS Code info into clipboard
body:
A lot of times I want to open issues directly on GitHub. Now if I want to provide VS Code's info, I need to launch the issue helper, fill in title / body, open GitHub link, copy the info from there.

I would want a command to directly get those informations into the clipboard.

title: Exclude gitignored files from file watcher
body:
I would like an option to disable watching of gitgnored files (i.e. add them to the `files.watcherExclude` option automatically).

I think this makes sense, at least I couldn't think of a use case for watching gitignored files. It might also help with [autorefresh related issues](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/42821#issuecomment-436627837) and could make the `files.watcherExclude` option thinner.
